articles.author: @wn_name
articles.description: Look at setting the header in your nginx reverse proxy config.  This has nothing to do with tt-rss.
articles.title: Unable to use fetch() on TT-RSS API

articles.author: @aurelebonvin Aurele
articles.description:
Hello,
I have a problem when I want to access API using fetch() with vue.js.
created() function of my component I make a call to the api in this way:
fetch('https://rss.mydomain.ch/tt-rss/api/', {
	method: "POST",
	headers: {
	  "Accept": "application/json",
	  "Content-Type": "application/json",
	},
	body: JSON.stringify({
			"sid": "API_KEY",
			"op": "getHeadlines",
			"feed_id": -3,
			"order_by": "date_reverse"
		})
	})
.then(response => response.json())
.then(data => console.log(data))

And I still get a CORS related error:
Access to fetch at ‚Äòhttps://rss.mydomain.ch/tt-rss/api/‚Äô from origin ‚Äòhttp://localhost:8080‚Äô has been blocked by CORS policy: Response to preflight request doesn‚Äôt pass access control check: No ‚ÄòAccess-Control-Allow-Origin‚Äô header is present on the requested resource. If an opaque response serves your needs, set the request‚Äôs mode to ‚Äòno-cors‚Äô to fetch the resource with CORS disabled.
I understand that I need to set up the ‚ÄúAccess-Control-Allow-Origin‚Äù header, but how do I do it on the tt-rss API?
TT-RSS runs with docker behind an nginx reverse proxy. I followed the installation as explained here.
When I use Insomnia/Postman, no problem appears.
I have already tried several things:
add mode: no-cors in the query
some solutions proposed in the topics of this forum, but the problem still persists.
articles.title: Unable to use fetch() on TT-RSS API

articles.author: @wn_name
articles.description:
GitLab is sending invalid XHTML, which LibXML (used by tt-rss) doesn‚Äôt like.  At minimum, img tags aren‚Äôt being closed properly in summary content.  There are probably no feed items with img tags when you see successful parsing.
Options including contacting GitLab to get that fixed, or creating a tt-rss plugin to fix up the content (likely by using the HOOK_FEED_FETCHED hook).
articles.title: Get Gitlab feeds working?

Since there is no other topic here discussing this problem, I‚Äôm curious about whether this is specific to the example feed below (unlikely) and/or whether there‚Äôs a way to remedy this.

articles.author: @linoth
articles.description:
I‚Ä¶ have concerns about the consequences of this post, but yes.
If your feed is accessible via a domain, i.e. http://mydomain/feed.rss then yes, it‚Äôs absolutely possible.  I‚Äôve done it for years, although I had to stop using localhost when the change fox mentioned went into effect.  I run tt-rss on an internal-only machine, and have for years, and it has worked perfectly fine, other than that one hiccup for security reasons.
If you want to do file:// or anything like that, then no.  The finer points of making a local file accessible via your web server while being secure from anyone-who-is-not-you may be outside of the scope of this forum, though.
articles.title: Is it possible to subscribe to a local-to-tt-rss file?

articles.author: @reibuehl
articles.description:
Hi all!
I have one feed where posts occasionally have links to MP4 files as media:content attached. The code in the RSS XML looks like this:
      <media:content url="https://files.mastodon.social/cache/media_attachments/files/109/584/612/582/360/330/original/5756bf06913dd6fa.mp4" type="video/mp4" fileSize="6684418" medium="video">
        <media:rating scheme="urn:simple">adult</media:rating>
      </media:content>


I am trying to filter on these posts and tried the filter regex ‚Äú.mp4‚Äù in ‚ÄúContent‚Äù and in ‚ÄúLink‚Äù but neither did match these posts. Is there a way to trigger on such attachments?
Reiner
articles.title: Filter on mp4 media:content attachments
